Floriano Jonas Cesar is an Honorary Research Fellow at the Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine at University College, London. His research interests include medieval political and ethical theories. He is currently studying the influence of medicine and philosophy in the political theories of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, especially in Marsilius of Padua’s works

title: Department of Political Science, School of Undergraduate Studies, Regent University (Virginia), as well as Associate Professor of Political Science. Besides various book chapters and articles, he is the author of Political Tolerance, Culture, and the Individual

His research interests include political tolerance, democratic theory, natural law jurisprudence and ethics, and the history of political ideas with particular attention to late medieval and early modern political philosophy

note: Brepols, 2003); Worlds of Difference: European Discourses of Religious Toleration, c. 1100–c. 1550 (Penn State, 2000); Talking Democracy: Historical Approaches to Rhetoric and Democratic Theory (Penn State, 2004); and John of Salisbury (Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies, 2005).
title: Nederman is Professor in the Department of Political Science at Texas A&M University. Besides over eighty articles and book chapters, he is the author or editor of more than a dozen books, including: English Political Thought in Early Fourteenth-Century England (Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies, 2003); Rhetoric and Renewal in the Latin West 1100–1540

note: Medieval Christian Philosophy) has been published by the Greco-Latin Press, Kabinet (Moscow), and his Politicheskaya Filosofiya Srednikh Vekov (Political Philosophy of the Middle Ages) has been published by the Thomas Aquinas Institute (Moscow).
title: Sweeney is Associate Professor of Philosophy at Xavier University (Ohio). His general area of interest is the history of philosophy; his specialization is medieval philosophy. A Fulbright Scholar, Sweeney taught in Moscow
